title: Memoirs of Hadrian
author: Yourcenar, Marguerite
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I will start with the observation: This is the book that made me regret again that I do not know French or Latin. Though it is beautifully translated I will start with the observation: This is the book that made me regret again that I do not know French or Latin. Though it is beautifully translated into English by Yourcenar’s long time companion, I could feel, that English is not the language for it. The sentences, craftily stylised, all follow the similar structure - main clause followed by a myriad of subordinate clause. In Russian (my native language) it would work fantastically. And, I am sure. in French or Latin it would read beautifully. But in English is it somewhat monotonous - you have to work hard to get to the layer of meaning. However, it is a very rewarding effort at the end.Yourcenar has managed to get into the mind of a person leaving 2 thousands years ago and to write on his behalf. The book is written in the form of the letter from Hadrian, nearing the end of his life, to Marcus Aurelius. Normally, in fiction one can see the writer behind the characters, writing style or even descriptions. One also can see the hindsight knowledge. Not in this book (with minor exceptions described below). The result is really unique - it is not a historical fiction - it is a recreated historical document. While starting reading it, I was asking myself while she picked up Hadrian for this. Fortunately, she gave the answer in the notes. She was reading Flauber’s letter where he mentions the time in the civilisation when the humankind disenchanted themselves from many gods, but the Christianity has not yet filled in the vacuum. So she became interested how people where dealing with the existential problems in that period. The book is very philosophic, dealing with the questions of immortality, love and the morality of empire; all of course from the perspective of Hadrian. It is interesting that in political spheres Hadrian was a supporter of piece and leaving the peoples of the empire to their own devices. Any cults and religions would be tolerated as soon as they do not offend the other. Sounds like a version of a modern religious tolerance in the democracy, I guess. He did not enjoy wars as much as Trajan, his predecessor. But there was one exception: the Jews“No people but Israel has the arrogance to confine truth wholly within the narrow limits of a single conception of the divine, thereby insulting the manifold nature of the Deitry, who contains all; no other god has inspired his worshipers with disdain and hatred for those who pray at different altars.” His generals has fought the campaign and suppressed the Jewish rebellation and made the Jews leave Jerusalem. It is shocking for me to read this (especially knowing what happens in the following two millenniums). However, I believe Yourcenar, that is how a Roman Emperor judge the situation. This ability to believe makes this book so powerful.It is also striking how much the Roman empire was directed to the East. Hadrian has spent the majority of his life dealing with Syria, Egypt, Judea and Greek territories. Yes, he visited Gaul and Britain, but they hardly played any role in the life of the Empire. This is very important to remember, when we study history and all European countries’ myths (including Russia) claim the inheritance of Rome. Only once i’ve managed to see Yourcenar’s silhouette behind the line: “I had long since made comparable exemptions everywhere for doctors and professors in the hope of favouring the survival and development of a serious, well-educated middle class. I know the deficiencies of this calls, but only through it does a State endure.” I do not believe Hadrian talking about the middle class role in the State. However, it might be just my limitations.In all other places Hadrian voice is very lucid. On the meaning of life: “each of us has to choose in the course of his brief life between endless striving and wise resignation between the delights of disorder and those of stability, between the Titan and the Olympian…”. On the destiny of humankind: it needs “perhaps of a periodical bloodbath and descent into the grave. I could see the return of barbaric codes, of implacable gods, of unquestioned despotism of savage chieftains, a world broken up into enemy states and eternally prey of insecurity.”On immortality (in the absence of one God): “Catastrophe and ruin will come; disorder will triumph, but order will too, from time to time… Some of men will think and work and feel as we have done, and I venture to count upon such continuators, placed irregularly through the centuries, and upon this kind of intermittent immortality.”And to finish on the lighter note, this book has reminded me a poem by Josef Brodsky, the Nobel Prize Winner, “The letter to a Roman friend”. The poem, as well as the book, is written in the form of the letter from a Roman leaving somewhere in the provinces to his friend, Postum. Brodsky is genial poet, perfect stylist as well. Respectively he is extremely difficult to translate. This is the best translation I found:Maybe, chicken really aren’t birds, my Postum, Yet a chicken brain should rather take precautions. An empire, if you happened to be born to, better live in distant province, by the ocean. Far away from Caesar, and away from tempests No need to cringe, to rush or to be fearful, You are saying procurators are all looters, But I’d rather choose a looter than a slayer. The full poem is there:https://www.poemhunter.com/poem/lette...PSYourcenar was a very colourful interesting character by herself. There is a great article in the New Yorker about her:https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/20......more

review: 2.5/5On a purely literary merit it is a big and tiresome slog. It is designed to be 10 volumes' chronicles devoted to the events which has lead to the2.5/5On a purely literary merit it is a big and tiresome slog. It is designed to be 10 volumes' chronicles devoted to the events which has lead to the Revolution of 1917. So the parts about the fictional characters are alternated by the parts about real historic figures and events. The construction is complex and really awkward. Initially the fictional parts were relatively lively with interesting set of characters and several story lines. But the gaps between dropping a particular line and coming back to it are too big to emphasise with the characters. So i stopped caring about the fictional parts.The historical chronicle is meticulously detailed and relatively slow moving. His method is to pick a historical event or a figure and drill so dip that it becomes overwhelming after a while. This book is devoted to two main themes: the beginning of the First World War from the perspective of the Russian front; the personality and the achievements of Pietr Stolypin, the Russian Prime Minister and strong leader, who was assassinated in the Kiev Opera in 1911 by a terrorist (at the same time the informer of the police), Merdco Bogrov. Those two historical figures are juxtaposed to each other for obvious reasons. But if Stolypin's life seems to be based on numerous sources, Bogrov's life and his motivation seems to be presented in more fictional way - it is unclear how Solzhenitsyn has compiled it. Solzhenitsyn presents him as a lonely, evil revolutionary who wanted to outsmart everyone (including the Okhrana) and succeeded. While for me, with the hindsight of another century, it seems more likely that he was the hand of the state secret service. There is a little episode about Lenin travelling to Zurich and this one is more readable. That is the only reason why I would try to read the second instalment of these chronicles. However, if one even manage to ignore monarchist, nationalist ideology (Russia is unique country in which democracy should be very different from the Western one - sounds familiar isn't it?) which is streaming from every page, it is still not very well written book.I've never read Solzhenitsyn before, so my view is based only upon this book. I've started the second part already (November 1916) and it is going a bit easier sofar. I do not think i plan to finish all 10 volumes. I will finish the second book and then probably dip into the rest. I read in original Russian.PSAbout the war - that the part i was not particularly interested, so I might misinterpreted some details, but the general story is relatively traditionally told - courageous soldiers, especially from the peasant backgrounds, treacherous, cowardly and incompetent HQ. Lies at the papers. There are two stories in the book. They are interwined in the middle through a carefully crafted connection. I did not know that the book came in two different versions - the half of the physical books started with one story and finished with another. The other half started with the second story and finished with the first one. What was that for? I do not know. But it did not affect my reading. Though it might, if my book would have the opposite order as I did not like the second story that much. However, the first story was very poignant, natural and vividly told - it was about the 16 year old girl who has just lost her mum to unexpected allergic reaction. And it is how she copes with her grief. Profound, sincere and penetrating, it touches the themes of identity, the healing power of art and friendship. And I really enjoyed to be in the company of this quirky girl, her brother and her friend. But relatively suddenly at the middle her story has been converted into the story of the 16th century painter. And it did not work for me at all. Initially I liked the tone of the almost Faulkneresque introduction with abrupt sentences. But then it has all whizzed out into a period piece which was not very interesting and authentic. As I said, there was a connection to the first story, but i wanted the girl to be back properly. The common theme through the whole book is the fluidity of gender. I think, three years since the publication made quite a difference how it reads. I think, if i would read it in 2014, it might be more cutting edge. She worked at the 60s and her life was tragically short. She was making colourful collages which might include someone else’s images, her artwork or some other materials. For me this novel is almost a self reference - it is a collage of little bits of life, poetic observations, miniature dialogues which are carefully patched together by Smith into the coherent whole. Some of these bits are really beautiful in terms of writing, almost poetry in prose, the different ones are darkly funny, the others are poignant.It has been dubbed as the first post Brexit novel. review: Have you ever listen to a piece of music when there is this reoccurring theme which repeats, but each time sounds different all the same. Different inHave you ever listen to a piece of music when there is this reoccurring theme which repeats, but each time sounds different all the same. Different instruments taking a lead, different pitch and harmony of sounds, but the same measured rhythm, the same notes.  It sucks you in like a whirlpool, in spite of you knowing more or less what comes next. And each time it sounds fresh.  This is how this book feels.  It is structured into 13 chapters corresponding to 13 years, each with the broadly similar cycle of events. There are many individual characters each is acting like a very short instrumental solo and then going back into the background to give the place to someone else. It is interesting study how you can develop a character fully with a few sentences devoted to them every 20 pages or so. But that is how the main character- the collective consciousness of the village - comes alive with the foxes mating, grass growing, stones falling and people going through the different stages of life and relationships. He does not even use the inverted commas for the dialogue (did Joyce called them “perveted” commas?). I think, it is to underline this wholeness of the narrative, the wholeness of that collective being.    Having read “If nobody speaks of remarkable things” so many years ago, I cannot refrain from comparing these two books. And I still like the first one more. But maybe, because it is set in urban environment and I am totally city person, or maybe i was different and it felt more dramatic. But this book is quietly wonderful as well.McGregor is inventive without being pretentious. This poignant narrative shows how, whatever we do, the life tends to be repetitive but random at the same time. It is like walking through the patI read Modiano not for the plot or characters, not even for Paris. I read him for the unique atmosphere he creates. It is like walking through the patchy morning fog: suddenly it lifts revealing you something unexpected and beautiful for a moment or two... and the it thickens again leaving you disorientated and lost waiting for another bright spot. His protagonist refuses to live life linearly. I imagine him almost squinting when he is trying to find these patches of vivid brightness in the fog of his past and remain there for some time with all his senses, oblivious to "today". We all feel this way occasionally; Modiano unlocks my own memories by association which I did not even know existed. I certainly tried to find the door to the little place in a different city where I stayed many years ago, where a lot of things happened which mean a lot to me. And I was very surprised, almost shocked that I did not know anymore which of one of these doors lining up in front of me I used to enter at least twice a day. I thought I would never forget this place. Can I rely then on my memory what happened there? title: Infinite Jest
author: Wallace, David Foster
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "The whole law of human existence is only that a person should be able to feel awe over something infinitely great. If you deprive people of the infin"The whole law of human existence is only that a person should be able to feel awe over something infinitely great. If you deprive people of the infinitely great, then they will stop living and die in despair. " Demons, F. DostoyevskyI was reluctant to start this book. There is so much hype surrounding it. Plus, I’ve read DFW’s two collections of stories, and they did not impress me as a whole - some of them are gems, but some of them where totally unreadable. You could see, he struggles to contain himself within the space of a short form fiction. The most importantly, I knew quite a lot about him. Somehow he resurfaced in different places and different sources, especially after his suicide, and he fascinated me enormously as an individual. I stared into the black abyss of his intelligence combined with the fragility of his personality and felt really insecure to pick up this book. You know, very rarely, but sometimes, you meet a person who is not simply smart, but has got this depth like a well - you look there and you see - it is deep, so deep that it is almost invisible where the water starts; and you know you would never be able to see the bottom in a dark water. It is not that you feel stupid in comparison, you simply feel scared and overwhelmed… Overwhelmed probably in the same way, as if you would be thrown into the Space, and see these endless galaxies getting closer, but never close enough. And you cannot explain yourself, why it is so terrifying, while it is so beautiful...I did not know much about the novel though. I’ve forbidden myself to read anything about it before I started actually reading it. I knew of course “addiction and entertainment” bit and the cult status (which was actually a bit off-putting). But eventually I decided the moment has come: and here I am - on the other side of the cover. And I am really grateful I’ve done it. It was totally unique experience. I never read a book which triggers such a combination of frustration and awe that the frustration becomes the awe by itself.As any great work of literature, it could be perceived on many levels mixing together the writer’s and the reader’s unique experiences; provoking the continuum of emotions, feelings and thoughts. For me there were two important ways of looking at this book:Existential level  “It now lately sometimes seems like a kind of black miracle to me that people could actually care deeply about a subject or pursuit, and could go on caring this way for years on end. Could dedicate their entire lives to it. It seemed admirable and at the same time pathetic. We are all dying to give our lives away to something, maybe. God or Satan, politics or grammar, topology or philately - the object seemed incidental to this will to give oneself away, utterly. To games or needles, to some other person. Something pathetic about it. A flight-from in the form of a plunging-into. Flight from exactly what?”This is the quote from the novel and the question which seems to be the central one for DFW. He would not give you the answer, but he would make you desperately search for it… Maybe, it is a flight from unhappiness and loneliness… Exactly not to happiness but from unhappiness. He makes this distinction between prepositions “from” and “to” (applying it to the classic phenomena of positive and negative freedom) in the novel. And, I think, here it is important. This “flight from” would be a motivation to lose yourself in someone else creation and sometimes to misstep the thin line between entertainment and addiction. This novel for me is a map of the huge, complex and tragic being of DFW himself. I think, it is not random that he uses the noun “map” to signify someones head and more broadly - personality. Borgesian conundrum comes to mind "whether the writer writes the story, or it writes him”. No writing could be more personal than this novel:- his experiences of tennis as more broad metaphor for desire to achieve, beauty and ability to face with your own physical limitations, ability to look beyond the fame; the fact that when you achieve any goal, it rarely brings the feelings of relief you hoped for… - depression - I’ve never in my life read such a powerful description of the Black Dog. The precision and ruthlessness of his language makes you really feel this abyss. He’s fought with this the whole of his adult life and eventually lost.- even his tendency for excessive sweating is reflected in the novel. There is a character, some kind of a guru, who literally helps tennis students to solve their life issues by listening to them while licking their sweat. - addiction and recovery - again, only person living through it could write about it with such lucidity. You can see, that he finds, at least partially, a solace among these simple people at AA meetings and half-way house; each of them with their own story of struggle. You can see, how he is surprised that their non sophisticated and not coherent philosophy is somehow more powerful than any mathematically rigid and philosophically cold reflection the humankind as a whole has come up with. But most importantly, this novel is a scream to be understood, to expose yourself as complex, vulnerable and defenceless as you are, to share yourself with other people. Not to be lonely:“Forget about so-called peer pressure. It’s more like peer-hunger. NO? We enter a spiritual puberty where we snap to the fact that the great transcendent horror of loneliness, excluded encagenent in the self. Once we hit this age, we will now give or take anything, wear any mask, to fit, be part-of, not be Alone.”But DFW does not want or just cannot “wear any mask”. He writes this book instead… he does not try at all to make it easy, he is not thinking about people who will read it. He badly wants them to get it, but he wants the readers to get it on his own terms without dumbing it down or chew it for them.Is it so different from what Rilke felt almost 100 years before him: “In everything which so dear and vital to us we are undescribingly lonely” ? The eternal curse the humanity is struggling with carrying away the great literature as its shield…Loneliness, to some extent, is another side of the individualism; or rather of the perception that each of us is totally unique and very complex. We really want to believe in it, especially, when it is so much propagated through our culture… Of course it is true, to some extent. However, there is this something which is bigger than any of us individually, which come to the existence only when we come together. As all our complexities can exist only if there is at least one other person who can understand them, or something different, something greater than a single human being…It is certainly a unique novel. However, it is very traditional great novel in terms of the questions it asks. Dostoyevsky was looking for “something bigger”. He’s founded it in Christian God. DFW is not so certain. He keeps searching…“But you never know when the magic will descend on you. You never know when the grooves will open up. And once the magic descends you don’t want to change even the smallest detail. You don’t know what concordance of factors and variables yields that calibrated can’t-miss feeling, and you don’t want to soil the magic by trying to figure it out, but you don’t want to change your grip, your stick, your side of the court, your angle of incidence to the sun. “ It is about tennis, it is about any creative process, it is about this novel and it is about life…Trickster levelNow, forget about everything above. I am starting again. Why “Infinite Jest’ as a title? Yes, Shakespeare’s Hamlet. But also there is this another matter. DFW plays with you all the way along. All through 1000 pages. And he does not let you settle into the text at all. The Beginning - you do not understand what is going on, you do not understand who are those people and voices. It does not make sense. It becomes frustrating and boring. If i would not find the audio of the novel on Youtube and if i would not need to iron 20 shirts, I would probably give up. But after around 100 pages it suddenly becomes to make sense: “You never know when the magic will descend on you”. And then, I picked up the proper book again and it has been with me for the next few weeks.The Plot - I was almost disappointed when, 400 pages in the book, i’ve realised there is a plot and the very tight one indeed (even if a bit too melodramatic in parts). By that time, I’ve started to enjoy the novel without a visible story line or gradient.Overall his approach is very cinematic. The structure is very disruptive - he moves from one seemingly unconnected scene to another exactly at the moment when you at least expect it. He also uses micro views, which i absolutely admired. He would describe some detail in a way as if you can see through the lens, framing. A fragment, that we are used to perceive with our eyes, but never form a conscience thought about:“He sits in the blue chair with a trembling Styrofoam cup of coffee and a paper plate of brownies into which he taps ashes from the cigarettes whose smoke the air conditioner blows straight back over his head.”And such stuff just keeps you in the book reading each single word, even though sometimes in becomes frustratingly boring, but very rarely for long. And you never know when something boring or technical is going instantly to turn into something shockingly brilliant.I would not talk here about the lexicon and the footnotes - a lot said about it elsewhere.And yes, the novel as a whole sounds like “it was real life’s real egalitarian babble of figurantless crowds, of the animate world’s real agora, the babble 342 of crowds every member of which was the central articulated protagonist on his own entertainment.”The Ending - where is the ending? Here the substance and the form of this novel really unite. And you understand the “infinite jest” quite literally. I, as many before me, went to the beginning. And those, the most frustrating first hundred pages, would start to make so much more sense that- i dare say- they have become the core of the novel! Though the second time around, it has filled me with such an existential sadness, that it is the time to come back to the beginning of this .PSJust a few thoughts:- this is certainly the one of the top 5 novels i’ve ever read. And it is the one of the hardest top 3. The other two were “The Man without qualities” and “Magic mountain”. However, in both of these cases i did not enjoy it 1/10th as much as I’ve enjoyed IJ.- if i’ve read the foreword by D Eggers beforehand, it would put me off for life. I do not recommend to read it before the book.- i wonder why no one really compared this novel to Bolano’s 2666. I felt a lot of similarities, not at least the presence of a trickster who exists somewhere beyond the novel and beyond the reality in a forth dimension, but directs the novel from there.- probably a banality, but he’s certainly influenced the generation of modern writers, and now his voice is disseminating through them. I now recognise it, for example, in a “Brief history of seven killings” by Marlon James which i’ve read much earlier. - just two more quotes:“No matter how smart you thought you were, you are actually was less smart that that.”“It’s always seemed a little preposterous that Hamlet, for all his paralysing doubt about everything, never once doubt the reality of the ghost. Never questions whether his own madness might not in fact be unfeigned.”...more

review: DemonsFirst of all, a little note. I’ve read the book in Russian, and normally I would  it in Russian as well. But I think the Demons are unjustDemonsFirst of all, a little note. I’ve read the book in Russian, and normally I would  it in Russian as well. But I think the Demons are unjustifiably overshadowed in the West by other Dostoevsky novels. So I wanted to write something to change the situation a bit.It is the most powerful novel by Dostoevsky. It is more profound than schematical “Crime and Punishment” and much less preaching than “Karamazovs Brothers”, though the later one is building upon the “Demons”. It is the only big novel by him which contains a strong political element along with the traditional psychology and his religious thinking. Some of the main protagonists are revolutionary terrorists. The similar people would kill the Russian reformist tsar Alexander II just a few years after the novel was finished. Among other things, Dostoevsky demonstrates, how the pure desire of power could corrupt soul. I do not have sufficient knowledge of the world’s history, but I think the revolutionary sects in Russia of the second half of the19th century have become the pioneers of using the terror for their purposes in its modern meaning of the word. Anna Geifman, the American scholar, in her book "Death Orders: The Vanguard of Modern Terrorism in Revolutionary Russia" shows a lot of similarities between the Russian terrorists and nowadays’ terrorists:“Converting concrete grievance into messianic aspirations and practical purposes into holy causes, they operate within distinctive parameters of a theology of Armageddon a final battle between good and evil in which at stake in no less than universal salvation.”It is a very modern novel in many other ways. The methods those terrorists (on the radical left) use could be a primer for the radical right who supported Trump in the recent elections: fake news; making everyone confused and disoriented; spread rumours as true facts and play on liberals’ impotency in certain issues; marginalising and discrediting the authority - all these "tools" are described in the book. I was shocked to find so many analogies with our time. However, the main purpose of the novel (imho) to show what a spiritual emptiness can do to a human nature. How unresolved individual existential crisis and the search for completeness might lead to a disaster. For those who read the novel for the first time, it is an imperative to read the chapter “At Tikhon’s” after the end of the part ii of the novel. Currently, they publish it as an Appendix. It was censored out by the Russian authorities at that time on the basis of its “unbearable realism”. It is a shocking and revelatory chapter summarising the essence of the novel. And it is impossible to understand and appreciate the novel with leaving the reading of this chapter to the end. In spite of all the bleakness, it is a very funny novel. I’ve read it for the first time when I was 17. And then it was shocking and tragic. When I’ve read it now, it has come across more like a farce. Generally, one needs to read Dostoyesky novels during the one’s teens, while you ask all those big questions about the meaning of life and look for the answers…. I think that is why Nabokov was quite cold about Dostoevsky: according to him, Dostoyevsky is not an artist.. May well be, I personally do not totally share his religious and historiographic views. But his work creates a huge impact on a different level - it is not about language, it is about daring to go deep into the darker side of human nature and coming back from there constantly balancing…I finish with the quote from the article by Rowan Williams: “What makes it (the Demons) so well worth reading now is its unsparing vision of what destructive forces come into the world when there is a vacuum of spiritual understanding. “По-русскиИзвестное высказывание, что история первый раз происходит как трагедия и повторяется второй раз как фарс. Так и для меня второе прочтение этого романа. Первый раз почти в детстве меня шокировали и трогали трагические аспекты. Сейчас - все более хаос и фарс. Жаль, что этот роман скорее всего в современной России может быть использован властью для маргинализации любой оппозиции и защиты статус-скво.А вообще роман про “меня ужаснула великая праздная сила, ушедшая нарочито в мерзость”. - слова Тихона из опущенной главы....more

title: Rise of the Robots: Technology and the Threat of a Jobless Future
author: Ford, Martin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The book is a bit patchy in the quality of its analysis. But, I guess, the author is pioneering the new area in a wider public discourse. I could not The book is a bit patchy in the quality of its analysis. But, I guess, the author is pioneering the new area in a wider public discourse. I could not find any other mainstream, relatively impartial and newer book on the subject. What I liked about the book was the detailed and clear analysis of the current economic trends, such as the decline of labour share in GDP, inequality, inability of recent graduates to find suitable jobs etc. What i did not find so convincing was the casual link between the exponential technology development and the depicted future apocalypses (aka feudal society with closed-gate communities and the crowds of savages around it). I’ve read thoroughly the described trends in the automation and the AI. They actually appeared less scary than I thought. For example, I thought 3D printers could in future replace all production lines (silly me). Apparently, they would be used more like our home printers now for small unique objects. The book of course talks about much bigger variety of technological advances and which jobs potentially would go. But overall the scale of the evidence presented is not matching with the bleak social scenario depicted in the later chapters.The main risk according the the author is the lack of jobs would lead to the sharp drop of mass consumption which would initiate the downward spiral. in the economy. I would argue though, that a bit less consumption would not hurt. We all complain about consumerism and its impact on our culture and the environment. I know that the impact should be monitored, and stopped at some stage, but per se, it is not such a bad thing.Fortunately, when i was getting closer and closer to the end of the book, feeling more and more desperate and grim, the author came to my help and gave me the glimpse of hope:“While the machines clearly seem destined to take on more and more work over time, there is no question that the economy will remain heavily dependant on human labor for the foreseeable future.”I personally think, the inequality, or climate change, or geopolitical issues (how silly is that in the 21st century!) might get us to that bleak feudal reality quicker, unfortunately, if we do not tackle them. Fortunately, the suggested remedies offered by the author might (if taken seriously) help to solve the current economic issues: universal income; investment into infrastructure; increased productivity (especially for the UK). He is a bit more sceptical about education - he considers it as a minimum requirement not to fall behind the curve. But imho, the school education level in maths and computer science in the UK and in the US is so primitive that by improving it one would definitely increase productivity. The book has also brought me some revelation: apparently Hayek was supporting the universal income in some form. There is a proper reference on his work in the book. I just put a quote here:“A society that has reached a certain level of wealth can afford to provide for all.”I cannot imagine Koch brothers or their tea-party grassroots quoting this one. Have you ever heard this one quoted in any political debate from the right?In spite of some subjective criticism above, the book is definitely clever, daring and worth reading....more

title: Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right

review: Dark Money“We have two unelected multibillionaires who want to control the US government and exercise the power to decide what is best for more than 3Dark Money“We have two unelected multibillionaires who want to control the US government and exercise the power to decide what is best for more than 300 million American people, without the voices of those people being heard.”This is the quote from the book which summarises it pretty well. Jane Mayer has invested a lot of her talent, courage and energy in investigating and telling the story of systematic attempt in privatising the democratic process in the US. The book tells the story how Koch brothers and a few others from 1% of 1% billionaires in the US has built the whole infrastructure of influence in the politics. Eventually, they’ve almost succeeded supplant the Republican party (according to the author).They’ve started 30 years ago from building the network which would allow them to start the battle of ideas (extreme free market ideology). In the 30 years they managed to build up the whole system - think-tanks; nonforprofit organisations through which they can donate money without the trace; grass root movement (allegedly tea-party is their creature). This network has helped them to win the majority in the Congress and totally derail Obama’s agenda while he was in the White house.Of course the book is not balanced - you can see only what drives the process from the right. But there is no comparative picture from the left. So it is difficult to form an opinion why (and if) the democratic institutions in the US do not represent the public any longer. However, the lack of transparency in the network of this people, indoctrination of the academia, influence on the rewriting the borders for congress election and many other things are simply shocking and cannot be right. They preach the entrepreneurial spirit and demonise the government. They quote Hayek and think that anyone is free to chose to be rich or poor. That would be wonderful. But characteristically, there is not a single first generation millionaire in this book - all of them are heirs to the huge fortune. On these grounds, I am not surprised they wanted to stay in the shadow of their creation to keep it credible. The attitude of these people towards the environment and the poor is simply selfish. Reading it I felt how Jane Mayer hates this bunch. Initially I was cautious, because in theory there is nothing wrong to expose people to different ideas in a pluralistic society. But the more I read the more I started to feel the same thing. Especially, hateful I found the story about the North Caroline where these people have managed to gain the control over the local legislature. They slashed the taxes and the spending. But not simply that. They had a go at a decent public education system (and this I find the most abhorrent):“The assault was systematic. They authorised vouchers for private school but put a vice squeezing on public schools budget. They abolish the incentives for teachers to earn higher degrees and reduced funding for pre-school in spite voters will. “it’s sad and blatant” (said - the Professor of English in the State University) - Pop (the local billionaire who got elected) “succeeds in getting higher education defunded, and then uses those cutbacks as a way to increase the leverage and influence over course content.” They also sponsored history project, which aimed to reorient state’s teaching by providing online lesson plans for high school teachers that downplayed the roles of social movement while celebrating “the creation of wealth”. So much for critical thinking in education.A few days ago Betsy DeVos (prominently features in the book) has become the educational secretary in spite of sheer demonstration of ignorance throughout the confirmation hearing. Lets see how she fairs.Some people said they feel sad after reading this book. I do not feel sad. I feel angry, but a bit hopeful as well - Mr Trump, being just blatant populist and the lier (no respect for him) has managed to win against all these money. As did Obama in 2012. So in spite of being immensely influential, this network did not appear to be 100% effective. And due to Jane’s work and courageous citizens alike, they will hopefully fail in the long run....more

title: Strangers in Their Own Land: Anger and Mourning on the American Right
author: Hochschild, Arlie Russell
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: First of all, I have to say that I absolutely admired the author’s work. It is a rarity to come across such an extremely clever, emotionally intelligeFirst of all, I have to say that I absolutely admired the author’s work. It is a rarity to come across such an extremely clever, emotionally intelligent and compassionate researcher. To be honest, I always believed that sociology is pretty useless as a profession and the field of study - some hybrid spin-off from the anthropology mixed with economics. But Mrs Hochschchild has proved me wrong. This book is based on 4 years of her research into the lives and beliefs of the republicans’ supporters in Luisiana, (most of them are tea party members). She came across paradox - Luisiana is highly polluted state with high record of dreadful industrial accidents and environmental disasters. Some people she talked to were the direct victims of this. However, they do not consider this issue as a cornerstone of their political demands, even if it would be totally in their economic and health interest. Mrs Hochschild takes this issue as a tool for helping to understand how is that possible. She courageously attempts to break “the empathy wall” between her and these people. (Which is a risky business - i would definitely suffer either from the cognitive dissonance or Stockholm syndrome).During her research she came to the conclusion that the values and beliefs of these people are the result of their feelings rather than their economic or other rational self interest: the feelings of their sense of honour, pride, but also anger, humiliation and fear. Mrs Hochshild constructs a metaphoric visualisation which she calls “a deep story”. “A deep story is a feels-as-if story -it’s the story feelings tell, in the language of symbols. It removes judgement. It removes fact. It tells us how things feel.”Imagine a long queue to get to American dream. Those people were told all their life if they work hard and obey the law, they would get their eventually. So they are patiently standing in the middle of this line (They are predominantly white, middle aged, male, Christian). The line has stopped moving and it feels even that it moves backwards. But they are not complaining (complains are for the “poor-dears” on welfare), though they feel stuck. They are used to endure the difficulties. And now they see people are cutting in front of them: “Black, women, immigrants, refugees, brown pelicans - all have cut ahead of you in line. But it’s people like you who made this country great. You feel uneasy It has to be said: the line cutters irritate you. They are violating rules of fairness. You resent them, and you feel it’s right that you do. So do your friends. Fox commentators reflect your feelings…And now you’ve been asked to extend the sympathy to all the people who have cut in front of you.” So they feel betrayed. They feel patronised, as in their view, they are told what they should feel, without naturally having those feelings. “Liberals are saying your ideas are outmoded, sexist, homophobic, but you are not clear what their values are”.Their daily reality and political views are constructed on the basis of this story. Of course social- economic factors exist: demographics (less and less white people), religion - belief in rupture for example, disappearing of blue colour jobs. But it is appeared to be secondary to their perception of the world.Mrs Hochschild describes quite a few of individual cases. Some of those people are easier to relate to than the others. Some of them are really the victims of circumstances around them, such as dreadful environment. Although you cannot call them “victims” as they do not like that word. But for certain cases, I have to admit, even reading their perceptions is very hard. For example, there is that woman in her early 60s, college educated with the stable white collar job. She thinks: 1) “Liberals do not give personal morality is full due, probably because they are not churched”; 2) to give some people jobs America needs to dig up veterans’ graves from WWII and bring them from France as “it has not been a good friend” 3) “there is a positive side of the war- manufacturing missiles, Humbles, sewing uniforms - it’s work.” 4) to create democracy on the Middle East everyone there should be handled the gun. “If the government takes the guns away. The same thing as the Middle East would happen here as people would no be able to stand for themselves.”It is difficult to get over the state of shock and anger when you read such a view. But it is very necessary, as otherwise the whole democratic way of life might be at stake. Mrs Hochschild thinks that there are ways to bridge this abyss - there are issues which could unite people from the different side of the empathy wall. So it is worth trying.Initially, I thought that people who support populists and demagogues are uneducated, ignorant bunch, misguided by the media (some of them are plain stupid). But this book has revealed much deeper roots of the problem. I really found this book invaluable as a starting point for understanding Trump’s phenomena....more

review: The book is certainly ambitious in its scope: it sets out the forces which are driving the world and how it would effect the future. To summarise its The book is certainly ambitious in its scope: it sets out the forces which are driving the world and how it would effect the future. To summarise its main idea, we entered the era of acceleration and exponential change in our environment: 1) technology 2) nature 3) market forces. But being humans we cannot adapt to the changes so quick. So we have to learn how to do it. It is not a bad book, but I had an impression of a half baked cake. I allowed myself to use the metaphor as Mr Friedman is consistent and proficient metaphors' user. And he repeats his favourite ones constantly. I personally felt it is excessive, and even slightly patronising. For example: "Mother Nature's killer apps" used for the adaptability mechanisms in the natural environment - sounds a bit far-fetched and unnecessary for me. Plain English would suffice. And there are a lot of them. I did not enjoy the repetitiveness of language and flair for labelling the phenomena ("the time of accelerations", "life long learning", "Mother Nature" etc). If the book was directed on the students at high school, I would understand. But it came across like unnecessary simplification for me.You can see the natural reporter - huge amount of lengthy quotes from conversations with different people and other books. When he talks himself (the reason I was reading the book) he sometimes is not very convincing; especially, when he talks how the humans are supposed to adapt and what they need to change in their behavior. I did not feel the originality of thinking there.The first part about technology is relatively informative. But there are so many names of well known companies and their bosses that it reads occasionally like a bunch of product placements (IBM, AT&T, Apple to name a few).There is a small part of the book devoted to the policies he would suggest for America. That was interesting, but not very well developed section. And i could not find the reasoning for his optimism (which forms the part of the title) apart from general belief in human nature and local communities. Overall, I could not say I did not enjoy the book, but I could not say I have become wiser as well....more

title: In the Name of Identity: Violence and the Need to Belong
author: Maalouf, Amin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book has been written almost 20 years ago. In these 20 years it did not lose any urgency. Is 20 years such a short term for the civilisation or dThis book has been written almost 20 years ago. In these 20 years it did not lose any urgency. Is 20 years such a short term for the civilisation or does the author touch upon the eternal issue? I do not know… But I found this little book very thought provoking . I’ve highlighted probably the half of it. So it was difficult to choose what to mention here… Mr Maalouf’s language is lucid, the ideas are profound, even if some of them might seem simple. I think, this is because they are very well articulated. I admire author’s courage and persistence of working through them patiently. The main premise is that our identity is multidimensional. There are numerous parts of it. And only its entirety makes every human being unique. However, if any part of our identity is threatened externally (be it ethnicity, nationality, class or religion), this part becomes domineering and might lead to many irrational and ugly manifestations. With this phenomena, he explains the bloody conflicts throughout the history of 20th century and our time.He points out that reciprocality between different human beings and between the person and the society would help to diminish this risk. His main illustration is the relationship between an immigrant and the host nation. (He is a Lebanese adopting France as his host country for the last 40 years.) He considers immigrants as bridges between the two worlds which ideally would help to cement the relationships between different nations. But he talks about two extremes: 1) immigrant thinks he could establish his little world and impose his traditions on the local population; or 2) the host country tries to make the immigrant totally reject his own cultural heritage. In both cases the person involved would face with severe contradictions within his own identity which would lead to a crisis. I’ve read recently a book where the main character was a girl of a mixed race. She posed herself constantly with the question “Which tribe do I belong to?” Following Mr Maalouf’s view of the world, it would be much easier for her to embrace both white and black “tribes”- or even better - to forget about the “tribes” all together and embrace herself as she is as a whole human unique being. I know that it is easier said than done. Especially when in the developed world, the identity politics is so fashionable and gives the politicians so much power to hypnotise people with rhetorics and then divide and rule…Mr Maalouf reflects on the phenomena of the globalisation a lot. He thinks, the globalisation makes literally everybody in the world feel marginalised to a certain extent (sorry for a lengthy quote):Everyone nowadays felt himself to be living to a certain extent in a minority, in exile. This is because all communities and cultures have a sense that they are up against others stronger than they, a feeling that they can no longer keep their heritage safe. Looked at from the South and the East, it is the West that dominates. Looked at from Paris, it is America that holds sway, But if you go to the United States, then what do you see? You see minorities reflecting all the diversity in the world, all needing to assert their original allegiances. And when you have met all these minorities and been told a hundred times that power is in the hands of white males, or of Anglo-Saxon Protestants, you suddenly hear the sound of a huge explosion in Oklahoma City. And who are the people responsible? Some white male Anglo-Saxon Protestants who regard themselves as members of the most neglected and despised of minorities, and who believe that globalisation is sounding the knell of “their” America. In the eyes of everyone else Timothy Mc Veigh and his supporters belong to the same ethnic group as those who are supposed to dominate the planet. In their own eyes they are merely an endangered species, with no other weapon available to them but the most murderous terrorism.Mr Maalouf’s response to the complexity of the world is by trying to reconcile all complex allegiances within oneself and try not to threaten others. “Everyone should be able to recognise himself in the symbols and no one feel excluded in the global narrative. Neither on a world scale nor within any society should anybody feel scorned, depreciated, mocked or demonised or be ashamed of his colour religion, language, name or any other ingredient of identity.” And, in future “Identity would then be seen as the sum of all our allegiances and within it allegiance to human community itself would become increasingly important until one day if would become the chief allegiance though without destroying our many individual affiliations.” It is just a vision of course. But I find it much more palatable than any alternatives which are so trendy nowadays.There are a lot of other issues discussed in the book: the role of islam in the modern day’s insurgencies and terror; the language and identity; modernism etc. I would pause only on one more remark he makes:“It would be terrible for the country have more reverence to its past than to each future”.How incredibly urgent it sounds when Russia is building its ideology on the nostalgia over the country which does not exist for a quarter of the century. And the the next American president has won the election by proposing “making America great again”. Mr Maalouf is very profound thinker and this book deserves a broad readership so everyone could pick up something enriching her/his world view (even if he/she disagrees)....more

title: Swing Time
author: Smith, Zadie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh gosh, I did not want this to be soo long! Apologies!3.5 starsI picked up this novel because, I heard, it was inspired by Elena Ferrante’s NeapolitaOh gosh, I did not want this to be soo long! Apologies!3.5 starsI picked up this novel because, I heard, it was inspired by Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan Quartet. I practically lived inside those novels, and the idea to read another story about friendship appealed to me. We are approximately the same age with Zadie and her two heroines were supposed to be our contemporaries. I has grown in a totally different social set up in a different country. So I was intrigued to find out, how their childhood experiences, their feelings, their concerns were compared to mine. In this respect the novel was a slight disappointment. Both main characters are not particularly interesting. If there is complexity in them, it is not easy to find. Tracy, the narrator’s friend, is relatively stereotypical based upon her background - white obese mother; black father in and out of jail; learning difficulties and the lack of respect for others. But she has got this gift of dancing, alas she does not use it properly. As a result, she “meets” all the expectations of failure and becomes nastier by the page. Smith muses: “Their speak of Tracey took a tragic dimension, for isn’t it only tragic heroes who have not choices before them, no alternative routes, only unavoidable fates?” But in spite of all the difficulties Tracy faces I was not convinced by the novel that she is indeed “the tragic hero with no alternative routes”. It looked to me more that she did not use her talent due to lack of simple persistence. The narrator is as well somewhat passive and flat. She observes other people doing something, making mistakes, enjoying their life, falling in love, fighting for their ideals. While she seems to be feeling not much, or totally unable to acknowledge and describe her feelings even to herself. She dumbs her boyfriend with the letter through the door - not very personal even by modern standards. Other her relationships are devoid of love, it seems.Respectively, the friendship theme in the novel feels very unfulfilled. There is no passion or care for each other between those girls, there is no driving force or even no competition; just nastiness from the one side and bitterness or indifference from another.Sometimes it seems, Smith tries to compensate for the lack of feelings by intellectualising: “Katherine Hepburn’s famous Fred and Ginger theory: He gives her class, she gives him sex. Was this a general rule? Did all friendships - all relations- involve this discreet and mysterious exchange of qualities. this exchange of power? Did it extend to peoples or nations or was it a thing that happened only between individuals?” But I found difficult to relate this particular theory to the forces driving friendship. The other plot line is the narrator’s celebrity boss and specifically her project in West Africa to build the school for girls. Surprisingly, I found this part more alive. After the novel has moved to West Africa, I was initially sceptical Smith would make it believable. But I think she succeeded more that i would give her credit for. She renders the locals as fascinating and multi-dimensional. The problems the project faces are authentic as well. Almost unexpectedly I liked Aimee, the celebrity. (In real life I would struggle to sympathise with any part of celebrity culture.) She at least tries to do something, even if she makes mistakes in many cases. It is supposed to be the novel of ideas: the relationships between children and parents; the idea of time swinging between different people, countries, lives; celebrity culture; dance as the way of expression.Within those ideas the domineering theme is question of race. Smith’s main heroin and people around her constantly think about this. The girls compare their skin - who is darker (they are both of the mixed race); the narrator says: “i was born half right and half wrong” implying her white part is wrong. And there is this feeling through the novel that contemporary black people feel the victims of cruel awful injustice done to their predecessors. And they sometimes make this feeling define them. Is it the best thing to do? It would take probably a separate essay to give any justice to this complex and painful question. There is no resolution at the novel as well. Only the narrator finds eventually that even her race is very relative as the african people consider her being white.Smith touches upon more broad question of identity: “Friendship rings began to form and harden around me, defined by colour, class, money, postcode, nation, drugs, politics, sports, aspirations, languages, sexualities… In that high game of musical chairs I turned round one day and found I had no place to sit.” I feel so sad that we need to define ourselves by all these boxes in modern age. Actually, i do not think it is totally like that. I never thought about any of my friends to be defined by these categories. And in majority of cases it is impossible. If you try to do this, you definitely end up like the narrator - unfit in any of these group and lonely.The narrator constantly thinking about which “tribe” she belongs to. Tracy’s dad just fresh from a jail talks about the brutal “tribalism” within it. But does tribe suppose to define more primitive societies?The politicians recently use the identity issues in constructing their policies and election campaigns. I think, the crisis of the Western values we experience now is partly related to this - we learned how to divide ourselves into groups and subgroups. We learned to find the differences and forget about the common matters. As a result we learned to look for enemies. One literary critic I know has got this idea of classifying the novels based the number of subplots. According to him, practically anyone can write a story with the single plot and linear time frame. Only a good talented writer can combine two subplots. Three subplots are unimaginably hard, and four are for geniuses (see War and Peace). Here Zadie Smiths is trying to work with the two and you can see how hard it is. She does not always keep them equally interesting. Two main protagonists have not got much in common throughout the story - similarly there are not many connections between the two subplots. And the structure tends to fall into two detached story quite often. I enjoyed her smooth silky writing. I can see that she is still experimenting with the form. And I hope her next novel would be more vivid and self sufficient. ...more

review: 2.5 звезд на самом делеБольше всего в этом романе мне понравилась обложка. Она как-то красиво и кратко описывает все то, что состоялось в этой книжке.2.5 звезд на самом делеБольше всего в этом романе мне понравилась обложка. Она как-то красиво и кратко описывает все то, что состоялось в этой книжке. Как многие здесь уже говорили, первая часть книги очень хорошо написана - интересный сюжетный трюк, который позволяет посмотреть глубже в природу памяти. Очень хорошо создана атмосфера детства и взросления в начале двадцатого века. Трогательные детали, оживляющие ушедший мир, зарождение чувств и платоническая страсть. Вот, если бы автор сосредоточился на всем этом, рассмотрел бы этот мир глубже, мне кажется, роман бы удался.Но, когда появились лагеря, я стала опасаться, что это ни к чему хорошему не приведет (в плане романа). Я просто не верю автору. Не потому что все было по-другому, а потому что это такая огромная трагичная и монументальная тема, что она не впихивается в этот сюжет вот так просто. Про это, мне кажется, нужно либо отдельно писать роман, либо оставить это тем, кто это все пережил.Потом еще хуже - зачем-то еще одна героиня с одинаковым именем и родственными связями, какое-то нагромождение голосов - непонятно, должны ли они отличаться или сливаться. Теория "дерьма" как движущей силы переворотов и преступлений. Наблюдение со слов главного героя, что может быть русскому человеку нужна тоталитарная система иначе - хаос. И много другого-разного в этом ключе. И в конце мы дошли даже до Федора Михайловича с его "тварью дражащей или право имеющей". Ну, он потратил по крайней мере целый роман, чтобы этот вопрос как-то убедительно для себя решить. А тут всего несколько страниц показалось автору достаточно.В общем, вторая часть - солянка сборная в лучшем случае. title: Pale Fire
author: Nabokov, Vladimir
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My initial strong impression was - Nabokov does not care about his reader. He cares only about his craft, the process of creation and the satisfactionMy initial strong impression was - Nabokov does not care about his reader. He cares only about his craft, the process of creation and the satisfaction it brings. His ability to squeeze the aesthetic effect from the language is magical. He plays with the words, their musicality - the amount of alliteration in this short novel is more than i’ve seen in a volume of poetry. His character says: “One can harness words like performing fleas and make them drive other fleas.” And this pretty much sums up what he does - His possession of the language is the one of a virtuoso jazzmen.He plays with the structure as well- not many writers would manage to weave a perfect poem, a fictional literary criticism and two parallel storylines into the canvas of a novel with slightly more than 200 pages. Although he does not particularly care about his plot either - it is almost a parody on a plot driven fiction with a darkly comic villain and slightly pathetic, a bit creepy main character.Yes, I thought, he does not care about the reader. I heard recently an interview with a modern, very talented writer. She said she always wanted to write a perfect short novel. But while she was writing she was thinking: “My reader would understand that and this based upon his/her preconceptions of the world. But it is not the case in my novel. So I should write more to explain this”. And her novel grow and grow. It is definitely not about Nabokov. He does not care whether and how he would be understood by the reader. He cares much more how his sentence sounds. So, I thought, this novel is more for writers. They surely would love it. But I could not relate to it.But slowly the magic of his work has put a spell on me. I read the poem twice and once aloud. He managed to rhyme 999 lines perfectly without any single stutter. His poem is very lyric, but it contains very profound themes as well. And simply it is amazingly beautiful.And the notes, apart from all these literary effects, contain unlimited cerebral themes. Below, there are just few which i liked, but you can pull out as many more as you wish really:- nature of violence: “The one who kills is always his victim inferior.”- “As many people of little culture, Gradus was a voracious reader of newspapers, pamphlets, chance leaflets and multilingual literature that comes with nose drops and digestive tablets; but this summed up his concessions to intellectual curiosity…”. This is the perfect description of a tabloid reader! And now we have a social media to deal with. How unfortunate that these people are exercising their democratic rights based upon this cocktail of information!- Russians’ character: “There is nothing metaphysical, or racial, about this gloom. It is merely the outward sign of congested nationalism and a provincial’s sense of inferiority - the dreadful blend so typical of Zamblans under the Extremist rule and of Russians under Soviet regime.” - not much changed there under the current regime, I am afraid. Again, nowadays it affects not only the Russians unfortunately.But overwhelming theme of the novel is the nature of creation. Can it be influenced from outside or imposed on the creator? Can its mystery be resolved at all?So I started from the premise that Nabokov does not care about his reader. But I changed my mind to the opposite at the end. He cares very much. He wants to lift the veil, even if ever so slightly, from the world we normally do not see. He wants us to look beyond the usual pleasure of reading and have a glimpse of this dark mysterious miracle of creation. And if he succeeds at least in a few cases, that is more than any writers could dream for.“We are absurdly accustomed to the miracle of a few written signs being able to contain immortal imagery, involutions of thoughts, new worlds with live people, speaking, weeping, laughing. We take it for granted so simply that in a sense, by the very act of brutish routine acceptance, we undo the work of the ages, the history of the gradual elaboration of poetical description and construction, from the freeman to Browning, from the caveman to Keats. What if we awake one day, all of us, and find ourselves utterly unable to read? I wish you to gasp not only at what you read but at the miracle of its being readable.”...more

title: The World of Yesterday
author: Zweig, Stefan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “People no more believed in barbaric relapses between the nations of Europe, than they believed in ghosts and witches; our fathers were doggedly convi“People no more believed in barbaric relapses between the nations of Europe, than they believed in ghosts and witches; our fathers were doggedly convinced of the infallibly binding power of tolerance and reconciliation. They honestly thought that divergences between nations and religion faiths would gradually flow into a sense of common humanity, so that peace and security, the greases of goods would come to all mankind… Today, now that the word ‘security’ has long been struck out of our vocabulary as a phantom, it is easy for us to smile at the optimistic delusion of that idealistically dazzled generation, which thought that technical progress of mankind must inevitably result in an equally rapid moral rise.”“Yet paradoxically, at the same time as our world was turning the moral clock back a thousands years, I have also seen mankind achieve unheard of feats in the spheres of technology and the intellect, instantly outdoing everything previously achieved in million years.”Reading this gives me harrowing and haunting thoughts. It feels like that for two reasons: how contemporary it sounds today; the person who wrote it, the European writer and cosmopolitan, had sent the memoirs containing this quote to his publisher and the next day, took his own life together with his wife in 1941 (in Brazil where he was escaping the Nazies). His name is Stephen Zweig.Amid awful darkness of the war, not being able to escape its shadow even after running to Brazil, from his beloved Europe, he remembers the times of his happiness and happier times for the whole world. He does not say so, but you can feel that he cannot forgive himself being so away from the tortured continent, like when he left his very old mother in Vienna just before it was occupied.The biggest part of the book is not about the dark days in his life. He talkes a lot about his childhood and youth during the belle epoch in a cosmopolitan Vienna. His voice is very engaging. He describes the places he visited, and he travelled widely, the people he had met. Many of them respectively famous like Rilke, Gorky and many contemporary politicians. His observations are very acute and sincere, sometimes humorous, sometimes critical, but always interesting.For example, he attributed the following to Rilke “People who spout their emotions like blood exhaust me, and so I can take Russians only in very small doses, like liqueur”.Or, in the times of hyperinflation “Incredible as it may seem, I can vouch for it that for a long time the famous, de luxe Hotel de l’Europe in Salzburg was entirely booked by unemployed members of the English proletariat, who could live here more cheaply than in their slums at home, thanks to the generous unemployment benefit they received.” But the book is the most poignant when he is tortuously and desperately trying to understand the reasons for the horror, why everything went so wrong, everything which was dear to him like his ideals, his culture, his friends has melted or had been physically destroyed in a matter of a few decades. He also blames himself for that: “But that overconfident faith in the future which, we were sure, would avert madness at the last minute, was also our own fault.”He never understood the necessity of passports or nationality, he always thought that there is something bigger that a nation, like the idea of Europe, humanity, culture. But as a victim of tragic irony, deprived of his country, stateless and haunted, he could not survive. He said “Bitterness - citizen of the world turned out refugee. “ And this contradiction as well as inability of escaping from the news about horrific reality, cost him his life.“Thanks to our new methods of spreading the news as soon as it happens, we have been constantly drawn into the events of our time…. There was not shelter, no safety from constant awareness and involvement….there were no way you could buy peace and quite; all the time, the hand of Fate took us and dragged us back into its insatiable game.” This as well seems to be the problem my generation faces.I know that history does not teach anyone any lessons unfortunately, but reading this made me once more aware how fragile our present and future was and how similar we were to the people who lived a century ago....more

review: There is no words in this novel, just pictures. In general, books without words, unless they are art reproductions, leave me totally cold. But this isThere is no words in this novel, just pictures. In general, books without words, unless they are art reproductions, leave me totally cold. But this is an exception. It is not a movie, and it goes deeper than words. That is why it is so hard to verbalise the emotions it triggers. But I think everyone who has moved from one country to another would relate to this little book very easily and would be deeply moved (no pun intended).It reflects so well on a whirlpool of feelings on arrival at foreign land: excitement, hope for the new life, painful or wonderful memories from the past and thoughts of people you care left behind. However, at least at the first stage, the prevailing sense is insecurity: you have to rely much more on the others, you do not understand many things around you, at least, no-one is interested in who you are… Why should they? At most, they feel aggressive towards you. You want to belong; be understood, but at the beginning it is a relatively lonely road.“you feel less confident, more distrustful of yourself. And I do not hesitate to confess that since the day when i first had to live with papers or passports essentially foreign to me, I have not felt myself anymore. Something of my natural identity has been destroyed for ever with my original, real self. And today, I am former cosmopolitan- keep feeling i have to offer special thanks for every breath of air that I take in a foreign country, thus depriving its own people of its benefit.” These are the words of Stephen Zweig, ” A man used to have only a body and soul. Now he needs a passport too, or he won’t be treated as a man.”I think many of us who changed the countries once or twice, even without dramatic reasons, felt this way sometimes. The images in this book have revoked in me those feelings from more than a decade ago. I did not know how powerful these memories could be.However, the dominating message of this book is hope. It does have a happy ending. It celebrates the differences between people, cities and habits; and it shows how those differences could unite people, not separate them. How all of us could understand each other and stay unique and special at the same time.The images to dig into in the minute of despair after watching the news…....more
